argument.name: UXWaitMessageTarget
argument.description: The type of wait message to show. This can be set to:

item.name: page
item.description: the entire screen is locked and the message is centered on the screen

item.name: container:*[js:containerId]*
item.description: the contents of a container specified by *[js:containerId]*

item.name: panel:*[panelId]*
item.description: the contents of a Panel specified by *[panelId]*

item.name: element:*[elementId]*
item.description: the contents of an element (typically a div) specified by *[elementId]*

argument.name: optionsObject
argument.description: An optional parameter that allows you to control the appearance of the wait window. See example below.

discussion.p: Displays a 'wait...' message over the specified target. The specified target is also 'locked' so that the user cannot interact with controls (for example click a button) that are in specified target. This method is often used at the start of an Ajax callback. When the callback is complete, the .hideWaitMessage() method is called.
You can have multiple wait messages displayed at the same time, each locking a different section of the screen.
Two types of wait windows can be created. You can use an animated gif, or you can use CSS3 transformations in place of an animated gif.
